entry.title: Seeking Guidance on Growing
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I hope you're doing well. I recently graduated and have been working as a Data Migration Consultant for the past four months. I'm excited to be part of the SAP ecosystem and eager to learn and grow.

Looking ahead, I want to build a strong career and see myself at a higher professional level in the coming years. Since many of you have more experience in this field, I would really appreciate your advice.

  • What skills or certifications should I focus on?
  • Are there specific tools, modules, or projects I should try to get involved with?
  • How can I develop both technically and professionally in this role?

Any tips, resources, or personal experiences would be very helpful. Thank you in advance for your support

entry.title: Trading Partner within MM Subcontracting Consumption posting
entry.content:
Hello,

we face an issue in MM Subcontracting with an intercompany vendor. We use MM Subcontracting for a type of repair service. We send the broken item with a delivery related to a subcontracting purchase order, the item in the order is the same material number. When we receive the item back, the GR Posting also posts the consumption of the item sent (special stock in sending company) with trading partner. But this item is never owned by the IC vendor. Because of the system behaviour we get in trouble with our consolidation team, since this entry can not be consolidated with the IC vendor, so its a one side trading partner entry.

The propsal of SAP support is an implicit enhancement which we would like to avoid.

Has anybody a standard solution for this topic or maybe a process which does not cause such an issue?

Many thanks in advance!

Regards, Marion

entry.title: Migration from 0UC_ISU_24 to Recommended Alternatives – Missing Fields Issue
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I'm currently working on migrating SAP IS-U DataSources to a BW/4HANA environment. The existing system is still running on BW on HANA. SAP provides a whitelist indicating which DataSources are considered obsolete and recommends suitable alternatives for BW/4HANA.

In our case, the DataSource 0UC_ISU_24 is actively used and business-critical. According to SAP’s guidance, the suggested replacements are 0UCCONTRACT_ATTR_2 and 0UCCONTRACTH_ATTR_2. However, we're running into a major issue: the recommended alternatives do not cover all the required fields. A significant number of fields are missing.

This seems to stem from the fact that 0UC_ISU_24 is based on a complex IS-U function module which pulls data from multiple tables, whereas the recommended replacements are far less comprehensive.

So here’s my question:
Has anyone dealt with this migration before and found a working solution?

  • Did you somehow reuse or copy the original extractor logic (e.g., Z-copy of the FM)?

  • Or is there another approach you'd recommend for getting all the necessary data into BW/4HANA?

Any experience, suggestion or direction would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks in advance

entry.title: Test environment does not display information on KE24
entry.content:
When executing the KE24 transaction it does not bring information.

After performing the homogeneous copy on June 10, 2025, transaction KE24 shows no information, but there is data at the table level. We don"t understand what"s happening or if something needs to be activated in the test environment. I clarify that transaction KE24 does work in the production environment; it displays information.

 

tables that display information:

CE1PA10, CE3PA10,CE4PA10, CE4PA10_ACCT,  CE4PA10_FLAG, TKEB, TKES, TKEZU,COEP

entry.title: What are the limitations of the flat fee 7018105 and 7018538 ?
entry.content:
Hi,

I have two customers with ECC contracts that include SKUs corresponding to the flat fee model, allowing them to transition from ECC to S/4HANA On-Premise.

Each customer has a different SKU, but both seem to offer the same benefit:

  • 7018105: S/HANA Foundation Starter
  • 7018538: SAP S/4HANA Ent Mgmt for ERP Customers

I have the following questions:

  • What are the limitations of the flat fee model?
  • Since their contracts are still ECC-based, are they affected by the end of maintenance in 2027 if they are on S4 with the flat fee ?

Thank you for your support.

Best regards,
Julien

regards

entry.title: SAP Factory Calendar Synchronization Use Case
entry.content:
Overview

In SAP implementations, the Factory Calendar (TFACD table) plays a critical role in scheduling and planning processes, particularly for manufacturing businesses with Make-to-Order (MTO) scenarios. This use case highlights the importance of timely synchronization of the Factory Calendar between SAP ECC, BW, and HANA systems to ensure accurate production scheduling and order tracking, avoiding significant business disruptions.

Business Scenario

A manufacturing organization relied on an SAP-based order tracking application to manage MTO processes. The application used SAP HANA Calculation Views and Table Functions to calculate order availability dates by combining the production order schedule finish date with goods receipt processing days, factoring in only working days as defined in the Factory Calendar (TFACD).

Challenge

In 2022, the Factory Calendar in the SAP ECC system was updated to reflect temporary changes in working days due to external circumstances, marking Fridays as non-working days (TFACD FRTAG = 0). This configuration was successfully replicated to the BW and HANA systems at the time. However, in late 2023, the organization updated the ECC Factory Calendar to reinstate Fridays as working days (TFACD FRTAG = 1). Due to an oversight, the "Transfer Global Settings" process was not executed, resulting in a discrepancy between the ECC, BW, and HANA systems.

This misalignment caused the order tracking application to inaccurately calculate order availability dates. For instance, when an availability date fell on a Thursday, the system incorrectly extended it to the following Monday, assuming Friday was a non-working day. This led to significant frustration among business users, who observed delays in order scheduling, impacting operational efficiency and customer satisfaction.

Initially, the issue was misdiagnosed as a flaw in the HANA Calculation View logic. However, thorough analysis revealed that the root cause was the failure to synchronize the updated Factory Calendar across all systems.

Solution

The issue was resolved by executing the "Transfer Global Settings" process to synchronize the Factory Calendar (TFACD) from SAP ECC to the BW and HANA systems. This action updated the working day configuration, aligning all systems with the correct schedule.

Outcome

  • Resolution Time: The synchronization process resolved the issue in approximately 10 minutes, addressing a problem that had persisted for nearly two years.
  • Business Impact: Accurate order availability dates restored user confidence in the system, improved production scheduling, and enhanced customer satisfaction.
  • Lessons Learned:
    • Timely synchronization of the Factory Calendar across SAP systems is critical for accurate scheduling and reporting.
    • Regular validation of global settings replication can prevent discrepancies in cross-system processes.
    • Collaborative root cause analysis is essential to avoid misdiagnosing issues as logic errors when they stem from configuration mismatches.

Best Practices

  1. Automate Global Settings Transfer: Schedule periodic execution of the "Transfer Global Settings" process to ensure consistency across SAP ECC, BW, and HANA systems.
  2. Monitor Factory Calendar Updates: Implement governance to track and communicate changes to the Factory Calendar, ensuring all relevant systems are updated promptly.
  3. Cross-System Validation: Perform regular checks to validate data consistency between ECC, BW, and HANA, particularly for critical tables like TFACD.
  4. User Feedback Loop: Encourage business users to report anomalies in scheduling or reporting, enabling faster identification of system discrepancies.

Conclusion

This use case underscores the importance of maintaining synchronized configurations across SAP systems to support critical business processes. By prioritizing timely updates and proactive monitoring, organizations can avoid operational disruptions, enhance system reliability, and ensure a seamless user experience.

The above mentioned use case was real life business problem encountered by the team and resolved.

entry.title: (Custom) Idoc: issue when changing data type of a field
entry.content:
Hello everyone, 

I've searched the forum, and I've found this old post:

https://community.sap.com/t5/application-development-and-automation-discussions/changing-data-type-in-a-customised-idoc/m-p/2138493/thread-id/450151 

I also need to change the data type of the field,  in a segment of a custom idoc.

The new field format is 18 char, while the old one is 2 char.

I did simply what they suggested in that post; however, now old idocs (of the same message type) are not displayed correctly in transaction WE02 - which seems unable to interpret the old content according to the new structure. As I increased the dimension of the field (I did not reduce it), I would expect that the old content of that field can be put in the new format with no issues..

Can anyone help me?

Thanks in advance

entry.title: Unable to convert planned order to purchase requisition
entry.content:
Hi,

We are running MD01 with the following parameters

Processing key: NETCH

Create Preq: 2

SA Deliv. Sched. Lines: 3

Create MRP List: 1

Planning mode: 1

Scheduling: 1

When MRP ran, it created planned order when it is outside opening period and cleared planning file entries which is expected. The material did not had any changes to stock or to requirements, hence, the planning file does not have any tick. If we run MRP in opening period using MD01, it will ideally skip the material and does not convert planned order to purchase requisition. How to deal with this scenario?

Thanks

entry.title: Best approach to trigger automatic email notifications for COFC error messages in SAP
entry.content:
Hi experts,

We are currently facing recurring COFC error messages in SAP, such as:

"A master record for 11030211/MACH01 exists only in 2021"

This occurs because the system fails to find valid pricing data for old work centers (e.g., SG20). If these COFC errors are not resolved within the current period, they can affect the accuracy of actual activity costs, delay settlements, and cause production variances.

To prevent recurrence, we are considering setting up automated email notifications when such COFC errors are detected. The requirements are:

  1. Automatically send an email to a designated PIC when a COFC error is triggered.

  2. Email title format:
    "COFC error for company code SG10 Plant SG17 as at <posting date>"

Question:
What is the best approach to implement this auto-email setup in SAP?

  • Is it advisable to use a user-exit, implicit enhancement, or custom background job for detecting COFC errors?

  • Which table(s) or log(s) should be monitored to reliably capture COFC-related messages in real-time or batch?

  • Any recommendations for sending formatted email alerts via ABAP?

Appreciate any advice or examples you can share.

Thank you!

entry.title: component consumption in a multilevel BOM in an order
entry.content:
Hello All

I want to create a functional specification for a Z report. I have a multi-level Bill of Materials (BOM), and I need to determine how much quantity of raw material N1 is used in finished material F1. However, N1 is not a direct component of F1’s BOM—it appears at a lower level in the BOM hierarchy. Although N1 is also used in other finished materials, I want to calculate only the quantity consumed in the production of F1.

I don't want this qty from BOM qty which will be available in CS11 or CS 12 report. I want qty of N1 as per daily confirmation done by user because F1 t N1 qty ratio is not constant.


Thank you

entry.title: Oracle on Linux Refresh Procedure
entry.content:
Hello,

Recently our systems migrated from Windows to Linux.
Our database backups are configured in networker tool. Both our application and database are on different servers.
Our concern, after OS migration we have been requested from the client to perform system refresh.
For that we are targeting our sandbox system i.e. we need to refresh our sandbox system with the production data.

Problem we are facing : 
We don't have any system refresh procedure for the Linux operating system.
We are not sure just by moving only .anf file (backup file) from source to the target system  will perform restore.
We would like to know from you what could be the refresh procedure and what will be the files we need to move from source to the target.

Note : We want to perform the restore with brtool option.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.content:

All settings are done in system, component is not batch managed material. When we create production order the special stock indicator 3 consignment is not set automatically. We need to do in manually. As we are using MES system for order handling we need this marker to be set on order creation cause if it is not than also it is not in the IDOC.

Thanks

entry.title: How to Join IDoc data (EDID4) with MSEG to Map REM Yield/Consumption to Planned Orders in SQVI?
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I'm trying to create a custom report for our business user in SQVI to replicate the output of MB51, which I want to display the REM planned order number associated with each yield/consumption posting. Current challenge that I'm facing is that in REM, once the MES system sends data via IDoc, the postings are created in SAP against a cost collector (unlike discrete manufacturing whereby the postings will be against a production order).

My objective:

1. To build a report that mimics MB51 (based on MSEG + MKPF).

2. In the report each yield and consumption posting will be linked to each planned order.

3. The report also can be filtered by posting/entry dates.

 

I have done a bit of study and I've found that these tables below contains the information that I need in the report:

1. EDID4: Contains SData which includes the planned/work order, material, plant, etc.

2. EDIDC: Contains the timestamp of the IDoc

3. MSEG: Material document items

4. MKPF: For header data

 

So the challenge that I face:

1. The planned order number is available inside EDID4-SData as part of raw string.

2. There is no common fields that can link EDID4 with MSEG

3. SQVI does not support parsing SData, so I cannot extract the planned order field directly.

4. I have tried to join PLAF with MSEG + MKPF, however once I have generated the report, the planned order number is incorrectly mapped to each transaction. For example, even though I have filtered the transaction date as 30th July, there are old planned orders (May planned orders) and planned orders that yet to release (Dec 2025 planned orders) are displayed in the report. 

 

Is there any way to make this work in SQVI? Or is a custom ABAP/Z-table is the only viable path? Thanks in advance for your insights!

entry.title: Adoption of PO price from purchase requisition for confugured material
entry.content:
Hello,

We have a configured material whose price in the purchase requisition is determined by the BOM for our intercompany process ( we developed some logic to transfer the EK02 condition from sales order to PREQ). The problem come when converting the purchase requisition to a PO. The PO overwrites the PREQ price with either PIR or last PO price, I understand this is standard SAP behaviour.

My question is is there a way to default the PREQ price automatically for configured materials when converting to PO.

Many thanks
